Title: Jet fire from a mechanical rupture in a compressor unit of an isomerisation plant
ConfidentialDescription:
<b>Responce - Seveso II duties  - remarks: </b>The On-site Emergency
Plan refers to accident scenarios in general, not to a specific event.
The On-site Emergency Plan is structured in relation to emergency
levels not to specific accident scenarios.
The documentation refers to hypothetical situations, which do not
strictly correspond to the specific event, nevertheless these have a
certain resemblance and relation to the event that actually occurred.
The evaluation process of the safety report was still in progress when
the accident occurred.
In the safety report the type of event that occurred had been taken
into account as a rupture of the compressor due to overpressure with
the forming of a jet-fire. The event was attributed an event frequency
of 6,5x10 E-8. The extent of the event was over-estimated in terms of
source (110 kg/s of release flow, against approximately 20 kg/s
evaluated for the real case), but under-estimated for the effects: the
domino effect involving nearby units was not considered. For the
jet-fire the radius of the damage zone was calculated as 140 m for a
duration of 10 seconds. The thermal collapse of the nearby equipment
was considered as unlikely due to the short duration of the jet.
Domino effects on nearby units are however mentioned in the safety
manual, in which the evaluation of potential interactions between
different units is considered.
In the information sheet a more severe accident scenario is also
considered although referring to different accident dynamics.
In the Onsite Emergency Response Plan the accident that occurred could
be compared with the accident scenario that considers the rupture of a
gas or LPG pipeline. The representatives of the refinery stated that
the procedure had been started to update the Onsite Emergency Response
Plan to the accident scenarios identified in the Safety Report.
The Onsite Emergency Response Procedure appears to be almost adequate,
it defines in detail the emergency response operations to be performed
in the plant sections involved, but needs to be improved, in particular
with respect to the location of the fire fighting equipment and
installations. A corrective action was foreseen with the revision of
the safety shut-down procedures of all equipment in the establishment
and the definition of new additional procedures.
<br>&nbsp;
LessonsLearned: <b>Measures to prevent recurrence: <br><br></b>Corrective actions on the On-site Emergency Response Management<br><br>Equipment<br>-&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; compressor orientation<br>-&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; vibration detection system<br>-&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; automatic cut-off valves at the compressor intake<br>-&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; functionality and location of the automatic shut-down buttons<br>-&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; electric powering system and sectioning<br>Emergency response planning and management<br>-&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; number and placing of the water and foam dispensers of the fixed extinguishing systems<br>-&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; number and placing of the monitors<br>-&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; performance of the extinguishing system in terms of delivery and capacity of the water supply<br>-&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; accessibility of the hazardous areas with extinguishing equipment<br>-&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; performance of the extinguishing systems of the refinery and accessibility of appropriate personal protective equipment for the emergency response teams.<br><br>- appointment of an interdepartmental working group, with the assignment to issue or supplement the emergency response procedures so as to better define the tasks both of the single emergency response team members as well as the tasks of operative personnel in charge of sectioning and shutting down the installations. The procedures will comprise specific checklists, made available also to the Emergency Control Centre, which will be more efficient in following and supporting operations on the field.<br>- verify the sewage system with respect to the suitability to cope with emergencies<br>- prepare a portable radio communication system, for use only during emergencies, in order to improve communication during emergency response operations.<br>- optimise the availability and location of personal protective equipment<br>- increase the possible intervention points, numerically insufficient<br>- increase the flow rate of the extinguishing water network, verify the performance of the extinguishing water network in terms of flow rate and water storage capacity.<br><br>With reference to the experience gained and the updating studies carried out the following measures are planned by the company:<br><br>Structures and equipment:<br>- substitute the reciprocating compressors with a single centrifugal compressor in view of developing the isomerisation unit;<br>-adopt electrically driven shut-off valves at the intake to be mounted near the compressor (the old valves were manually driven), so as to significantly limit any possible gas leakage;<br>- improve the placing of hydrants and fixed monitors. <br><br>Concerning management and documentation aspects:<br>- improve the localisation of personal protective equipment;<br>- improve the training of the personnel concerning the management of emergencies; systematic call-up of the emergency response team with drills every 15 days;<br>- define for all equipment the sequence of operations needed to secure the equipment;<br>- overhaul the electric securing systems of the machines, defined as a priority with respect to securing the process equipment;<br>- update the risk analysis carried out for the safety report;<br>- start the necessary procedures to tune the on-site emergency plan to the accident scenarios identified in the safety report.<br><br>

Reasons.ItemDescription: Substances involved: greater than 5% of quantity in Column 3 of Annex I
Injury to persons: >= 1 fatalities, >= 6 hospitalizing injuries etc.
Immediate damage to the environment (according to Annex VI)

AccidentDescription: At 15:03 hrs in the isomerisation unit a mechanical rupture in one out of two compressors occurred. The compressors, which were working in parallel and were operating at a pressure of 20 bars, were dedicated to conveying the gas mixture needed for the isomerisation process. The rupture caused the release of a gas mixture containing hydrogen, which on coming into contact with air ignited forming a jet fire. The jet fire headed towards the adjacent benzene saturation (BenSat) section hitting the nearest equipment (a pressure vessel) located 14 m from the release point. Weakening of the BenSat structure, consequent release of benzene from these structures and extension of the fire, with substantial destruction of the section. The length of the jet-fire could not be calculated with precision because the flame hit against the nearby BenSat unit; if the jet had not been stopped by the BenSat unit, it could have had an estimated length of approximately 30 m.<br>Off-site fire brigade teams intervened extinguishing the fire within approximately 1 hour and a half of work. No damage was reported to persons or to the environment.<br><br>

Site_Description: <b></b>The accident originated in the isomerisation unit (plant 129) and propagated to the benzene saturation unit (BenSat). The accident source is the reciprocating compressor K-2901B operating in a pressure range of 15 to 21 bars, equipped with two cylinders sized to transfer hydrogen mixtures to the isomerisation unit and to the BenSat unit.<br><br><table><tbody><tr><td><br></td><td><br></td><td><br></td><td><br></td></tr></tbody></table>
Installation_Description:
The accident originated in the isomerisation unit (plant 129)
and propagated to the benzene saturation unit (BenSat). The accident
source is the reciprocating compressor K-2901B operating in a pressure
range of 15 to 21 bars, equipped with two cylinders sized to transfer
hydrogen mixtures to the isomerisation unit and to the BenSat unit.<br><b><br></b><br>

Description: Pressurised hydrogen gas; C.A.S. No: 133-74-0, compressed highly flammable gas (F+, R12); can form explosive mixtures with air, can react violently with oxidants; approximately 300 kg of pure hydrogen were released.<br><br>Gas mixture of methane (C.A.S. No: 74-82-8), ethane (C.A.S. No: 74-84-0), propane (C.A.S. No: 74-98-6) and butane (C.A.S. No: 106-97-8). Extremely flammable non toxic mixture. Approximately 2700 kg were released.<br><br>H2 was the most dangerous substance in the released mixture.<br><br>Total released quantities (approximation):<br>- 3 tons gas highly flammable gas mixture from the isomerisation unit and 0.3 t mixture of the BenSat unit, in total approximately 3.3 tons of highly flammable gas mixture with 70% volume of H2, corresponding to approximately 10% in weight.<br>- 6 tons gasoline from the isomerisation unit and 6 t gasoline present in the BenSat for a total of 12 tons of gasoline.<br><b><br></b>ISOMERISATION UNIT<br>The quantity of released substances was estimated considering the volumes of the plant section involved (isomerisation unit); it has been estimated that a quantity of 3 tons of hydrogen rich gas mixture was present; while based on the volume of the two separators, considered to be filled to 50%, the amount of gasoline present was estimated at 6 tons.<br>The amount of hydrogen rich gas mixture released corresponds to 3 tons, because the feed of the hydrogen rich gas mixture was cut off in the first phase of the accident by the automatic emergency shut-down system of the plant; subsequently the manual valves located on the feed line of the gas mixture from the platformer and the valves installed at the battery limit were closed. <br>The amount of hydrogen rich gas mixture released by the compressor in the first phase of the accident was estimated using as a reference the progressive gas pressure decrease registered; during the first 4 minutes approximately 2.5 tons of gas mixture were released.<br><br>BENSAT UNIT<br>From the volume of the plant section the quantity of hydrogen rich mixture was estimated at approximately 0.3 tons, while the amount of gasoline present was estimated at 6 tons. It was assumed that all the product present fed the fire, while the feeding of the plant was shut-off at the beginning of the occurrence.<br>The estimated total quantities of released substances correspond therefore to 3.3 tons of hydrogen rich gas mixture and 12 tons of gasoline.<br><br>The continuous process is fed by large capacity tanks. In estimating the potential quantities that could have been involved in absence of safety measures, it was assumed that at least the manual valves at the battery limits would have been shut-off. The operator declared that maximally 7000 m3 of hydrogen rich gas mixture and approximately 20 tons of products in liquid phase could have been released from the two units involved, if only the feed lines at the battery limits had been shut.<br><br>Maximum amount of substances registered in the plant inventory<br>- approximately 25,000 m3 of hydrogen rich gas mixture, therefore 1,500 m3 of pure hydrogen (approximately 1,5 tons).<br>- 147000 t of liquid automotive petrol.<br>The establishment extends over a surface of 100 ha.<br><br>

SubstancesInvolved.Substance: automotive petrol and other petroleum spirits

Causes_Description: The accident was caused by the mechanical rupture of the bottom of the reciprocating compressor in the isomerisation section. This rupture was probably caused by a failure of the crank mechanism made of piston rod and drive shaft that caused the beating of the piston on the cylinder-bottom of the compressor. The combined effect of the beating and of the operation pressure may have caused the failure of the nuts holding the cylinder bottom; the following energy release threw the cylinder bottom weighing 100 kg approximately 14 meters away.<br>Due to the fact that the process control records did not register significant changes in the process parameters it has to be assumed that the failure of the crank mechanism was caused by aspects linked to maintenance or by a material defect.<br>At time of this report investigations were being performed on the material fragments of the failed crank components. An official systematic investigation on the failure cause with an expert appointed by the court is expected.<br><br>The clearance in the compressor between piston and cylinder bottom is 3 mm. According to the declarations of the operator, it appears evident that a mechanical interference between cylinder bottom and drive shaft may have occurred.<br><br>The nuts holding the failed cylinder bottom were found with completely abraded threads whereas the bolts on the contrary were practically undamaged and a few were just slightly blackened.<br><br>The flammable gas mixture was probably ignited by the beating and the friction of the failed crank mechanism or by an electrostatic charge built up through gas seepage.<br><br>

CausesHumans.ItemDescription: operator health (includes ailments, intoxication, death, etc.)
wilful disobedience/failure to carry out duties

CausesExternals.ItemDescription: utilities failure (electricity, gas, water, steam air, etc.)

Consequence_Description:
<b></b>Substantial destruction of the BenSat unit; only a small part of the equipment could be recovered. In the isomerisation unit the loss of the compressor was registered, the compressor had practically to be completely substituted and was taken back into service in June 2003. For some months the isomerisation unit worked only with compressor K2901A.

At time of this report a quantification of the repair costs was not possible.<br><br>The accident could have caused more severe damage without the adoption of effective response measures and the joint effort of the on-site personnel and the off-site fire brigades; even if the on-site emergency response organisation could be improved.<br><br>Affected Area: installation<br><br><br>
